lexUnit.name: exude.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: (with reference to moisture or a smell) discharge slowly and steadily.

sentence.text: If the property has been lived in for a long time with old carpets that have never been shampooed they can exude quite pungent odours .
She ventured upon deck the first morning , and was approached by not one but three potential beaux , each with his hair curled and exuding a powerful odour of bergamot .
The stewardess came down the aisle , a big-breasted young woman exuding a strong odour of perspiration .
Nevertheless he exuded pheromones and she saw two elderly ladies from the ferry clutch each other 's arms and whisper .
Some squirt formic acid , while others exude foul-smelling substances from their anal glands .
He exuded masculinity in the way that a flame gave out heat .
Queen of Night incense smokelessly exuded a heady perfume into the air .
The caterpillar of a butterfly called Thisbe irenea has a sound-producing organ in its head for summoning ants , and a pair of telescopic spouts near its rear end which exude seductive nectar .
The North American milkweed , if it is damaged , exudes a milky sap .

When David was Adam 's age he 'd taken to lighting joss sticks in his bedroom and anointing himself with patchouli , assuming that it disguised the faint but unmistakeable musty-sweet aroma that was exuded from his pores and lingered in the atmosphere .
Set into the floor were several open pits , which exuded a dank stench even as they pulsed with the chill luminescence of putrefaction .

Long and low-ceilinged , with an enormous open fireplace , it exuded warmth and the sort of comfortable feel that a perfectly decorated interior could give when it was neither pretentious nor over-grand for the surroundings .

The perfumes and aromas exuded by their leaves and flowers on a warm sunny day give any garden a fourth dimension , and one of the charms of the Greek and Italian hillsides is the pungently aromatic fragrance given off by the herbs and shrubs .
